functions.name: setProperty
functions.description:
Sets the specified key to the specified value if the property is within the script's scope.
Note: Care should be taken when setting system properties (sys_properties) using this method as it causes a system-wide cache flush. Each flush can cause system degradation while the caches rebuild. If a value must be updated often, it should not be stored as a system property. In general, you should only place values in the sys_properties table that do not frequently change.

functions.description:
Calculate the difference between two dates using the default calendar.
Calendars are now legacy. If Schedules are being used, see the topic Calculate Duration Given a Schedule.

functions.name: dateDiff
functions.description:
Calculates the difference between two dates.
This method expects the earlier date as the first parameter and the later date as the second parameter; otherwise, the method returns the difference as a negative value. Use getDisplayValue() to convert the strings to the expected format.
This method expects parameters in the user/system date time format, which may not be the same as the internal format. Using parameters in formats other than the user/system date time format may return invalid results.
If you are working with GlideDateTime objects use the GlideDateTime subtract() method instead of dateDiff().

functions.name: getMessage
functions.description:
Retrieves translated messages to display in the UI.
If the specified string exists in the database for the current language, then the translated message is returned. If the specified string does not exist for the current language, then the English version of the string is returned. If the string does not exist at all in the database, then the ID itself is returned.
If the UI message has a tick ('), there may be issues with the message in the script; to escape the ticks ('), use getMessageS(String, Object).

functions.name: getMessageS
functions.description:
Retrieves translated messages to display in the UI and escapes all ticks (').
If the specified string exists in the database for the current language, then the translated message is returned. If the specified string does not exist for the current language, then the English version of the string is returned. If the string does not exist at all in the database, then the ID itself is returned. Useful if you are inserting into a JavaScript expression from Jelly.

functions.description: Returns a session client value previously set with putClientData(). Session client data is a set of named strings that may be setup on the server (using putClientData()) that then may be used by client scripts (using getClientData()). Can be used during form load time to get information that the client script needs to make decisions about the form, for example, which fields should be visible.

functions.description: Adds an icon on a fields label. Adding the same item twice is prevented; however, you can add the same icon with a different title. Note: This method is not supported by Service Catalog.

functions.description: Removes all informational and error messages from the top of the form. Removes informational and error messages added with g_form.addInfoMessage() and g_form.addErrorMessage().

functions.name: clearOptions
functions.description: Removes all options from the choice list.

functions.name: clearValue

functions.name: disableAttachments
functions.description: Prevents file attachments from being added. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: enableAttachments
functions.description: Allows file attachments to be added. Shows the paper clip icon. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: flash
functions.description: Used to draw attention to a particular field. Flashes the specified color the specified number of times in the specified field. This method is not supported by Service Catalog. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: getActionName
functions.description: Returns the most recent action name, or, for a client script, the sys_id of the UI action clicked. Note: Not available in Wizard client scripts.

functions.name: getBooleanValue
functions.description: Returns a Boolean value for the specified field.

functions.name: getControl
functions.description: Returns the HTML element for the specified field. Compound fields may contain several HTML elements. This method is generally not necessary as there are built-in methods that use the fields on a form. If the field is a reference field and the control is a choice list, getControl() may not return a control as expected. In this case, use sys_select.<table name>.<field name>. This method is not available in mobile scripts or Service Portal scripts.

functions.name: getDecimalValue
functions.description: Returns the decimal value of the specified field.

functions.name: getElement
functions.description: Returns the HTML element specified by the parameter. Compound fields may contain several HTML elements. This method is generally not necessary as there are built-in methods that use the fields on a form. This method is not available in mobile scripts or Service Portal scripts.

functions.name: getFormElement
functions.description: Returns the HTML element for the form. This method is not available in mobile scripts or Service Portal scripts.

functions.name: getHelpTextControl

functions.name: getIntValue

functions.name: getLabelOf
functions.description: Returns the plain text value of the field label.

functions.name: getOption
functions.description: Returns the option element for a selected box named fieldName where choiceValue matches the option value.

functions.name: getReference
functions.description: Returns the GlideRecord for a specified field. If a callback function is present, this routine runs asynchronously. The browser (and script) processing continues normally until the server returns the reference value, at which time, the callback function is invoked. If a callback function is not present, this routine runs synchronously and processing halts (causing the browser to appear to hang) while waiting on a server response. Callback function support for ServiceCatalogForm.getReference is available.

functions.name: getRelatedListNames
functions.description: Returns an array of related lists from the current form in the order in which they appear on that form.

functions.name: getSectionNames
functions.description: Returns all section names, whether visible or not.

functions.name: getSections
functions.description: Returns an array of the form's sections. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: getTableName
functions.description: Returns the name of the table to which this record belongs. On the server side, the table for the current record can be retrieved with current.sys_class_name or current.getTableName().

functions.name: getUniqueValue

functions.name: getValue

functions.description: Hides the error message placed by showErrorBox(). Whenever possible, use hideFieldMsg() rather than this method whenever possible.

functions.name: hideFieldMsg
functions.description: Hides the last message placed by showFieldMsg().

functions.name: hideFieldMsg
functions.description: Hides the messages placed by showFieldMsg().

functions.name: hideRelatedList
functions.description: Hides the specified related list on the form. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: hideRelatedLists
functions.description: Hides all related lists on the form. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: isLiveUpdating
functions.description: Returns true while a live update is being done on the record the form is showing. This can be used in an onChange() client script to determine if a change to the record is because of a live update from another session. The client script can then decide what action to take, or not to take. This applies to systems using UI16 with live forms enabled.

functions.name: isMandatory
functions.description: Returns true if the field is mandatory.

functions.name: isNewRecord
functions.description: Returns true if the record has never been saved.

functions.name: isSectionVisible
functions.description: Returns true if the section is visible.

functions.name: onUserChangeValue
functions.description:
Registers a custom event listener that detects when any field in the current form is modified by a user.
When a form field is modified, the event listener calls the function that is passed in when the listener is initially registered. This listener is only triggered when a user makes a change to a field on the form. Changes from client scripts, UI policies, or any other non-user interactions, do not trigger the listener.

functions.name: refreshSlushbucket
functions.description: You can update a list collector variable.

functions.name: removeDecoration
functions.description: Removes the icon from the specified field that matches the icon and title. Note: This method is not supported by Service Catalog.

functions.name: removeDecoration
functions.description: Removes the icon from the specified field that matches the icon, title, and color. Note: This method is not supported by Service Catalog.

functions.name: removeOption
functions.description: Removes the specified option from the choice list.

functions.name: save
functions.description: Saves the record without navigating away (update and stay).

functions.name: setDisabled
functions.description: Makes the specified field available or unavailable.

functions.name: setDisplay
functions.description: Displays or hides a field. This method cannot hide a mandatory field with no value. If the field is hidden, the space is used to display other items. Whenever possible, use a UI policy instead of this method.

functions.name: setLabelOf
functions.description: Sets the plain text value of the field label. Note: This method is not supported by Service Catalog.

functions.name: setMandatory
functions.description: Makes the specified field mandatory. Whenever possible, use a UI policy rather than this method.

functions.name: setReadOnly
functions.description: Makes the specified field read only or editable. Whenever possible, use a UI policy instead of this method. To make a mandatory field read-only, you must first remove the mandatory requirement for that field by using the setMandatory() method.

functions.name: setSectionDisplay
functions.description: Shows or hides a section.

functions.name: setValue
functions.description: Sets the value of a field. When defining a value in a choice list, be sure to use number value rather than the label. To improve performance by preventing a round trip, include a display value in addition to the value, use setValue(fieldName, value, displayValue).

functions.name: setValue
functions.description: Sets the value and display value of the specified field. When defining a value in a choice list, be sure to use number value rather than the label. To improve performance by preventing a round trip when setting the value for a reference field, use this method not setValue(fieldName, value). When setting multiple reference values for a list collector field, arrays can be passed in the second and third parameters.

functions.name: setVisible
functions.description: Displays or hides the field. If the field is hidden, the space is left blank. This method cannot hide mandatory fields with no value. Use UI Policy rather than this method whenever possible.

functions.name: showErrorBox
functions.description: Displays an error message under the specified form field (either a control object or the name of the field). If the control or field is currently off the screen, the form scrolls to the control or field. A global property (glide.ui.scroll_to_message_field) is available that controls automatic message scrolling when the form field is off screen (scrolls the form to the control or field). The showFieldMsg() method is a similar method that requires a type parameter.

functions.name: showErrorBox
functions.description: Displays an error message under the specified form field (either a control object or the name of the field). If the control or field is currently off the screen and the scrollForm parameter is true, the form scrolls to the control or field. A global property (glide.ui.scroll_to_message_field) is available that controls automatic message scrolling when the form field is off screen (scrolls the form to the control or field). The showFieldMsg() method is a similar method that requires a type parameter.

functions.name: showFieldMsg
functions.description: Displays either an informational or error message under the specified form field (either a control object or the name of the field). If the control or field is off the screen, the form is scrolled to the field. A global property (glide.ui.scroll_to_message_field) is available that controls automatic message scrolling when the form field is off screen (scrolls the form to the control or field). The showErrorBox() method is a shorthand method that does not require the type parameter.

functions.name: showFieldMsg
functions.description: Displays either an informational or error message under the specified form field (either a control object or the name of the field). If the control or field is currently off the screen and scrollForm is true, the form is scrolled to the field. A global property (glide.ui.scroll_to_message_field) is available that controls automatic message scrolling when the form field is off screen (scrolls the form to the control or field). The showErrorBox() method is a shorthand method that does not require the type parameter.

functions.name: showRelatedList
functions.description: Displays the specified related list on the form. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: showRelatedLists
functions.description: Displays all the form's related lists. This method is not available on the mobile platform. If this method is run on a mobile platform, no action occurs.

functions.name: submit
functions.description: Saves the record. The user is taken away from the form, returning them to where they were.

functions.name: submit
functions.description: Performs the UI action specified by the parameter.

functions.name: addDecoration
functions.description: Adds a decorative icon next to a field.

functions.name: getLabel
functions.description: Gets the form label text.

functions.name: hasField
functions.description: Determines if a field is present on the form. Present means that it can be shown, not that it is visible.

functions.name: removeDecoration
functions.description: Removes a decorative icon from next to a field.

functions.name: setLabel
functions.description: Sets the form label text.

functions.name: addActiveQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return active records.

functions.name: addDomainQuery
functions.description: Changes the domain used for the query from the user's domain to the domain of the provided GlideRecord. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addEncodedQuery
functions.description: Adds an encoded query to other queries that may have been set. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addFunction
functions.description: Applies a pre-defined GlideDBFunctionBuilder object to a record. Use the GlideDBFunctionBuilder scoped class to define a function. After the function is defined, use the addFunction(Object function) method to apply the function to a record.

functions.name: addInactiveQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return inactive records. Inactive records have the active flag set to false.

functions.name: addJoinQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records based on a relationship in a related table. For example, find all the users that are in the database group (users via sys_user_grmember table). Another example would be find all problems that have an assigned incident (problems via the incident.problem_id relationship). This is not a true database join; rather, addJoinQuery() adds a subquery. So, while the result set is limited based on the join, the only fields that you have access to are those on the base table (those which are in the table with which the GlideRecord was initialized). Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addNotNullQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records where the specified field is not null.

functions.name: addNullQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records where the specified field is null.

functions.name: addQuery
functions.description: Provides the ability to build a request, which when executed, returns the rows from the specified table that match the request. If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the class GlideQueryCondition. addQuery() is typically called with three parameters; table field, operator, and comparison value. It can be called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as myObj.addQuery('category','Hardware');. The operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to". Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: applyTemplate
functions.description: Apply a template record (from sys_template) to the current record. If the specified template is not found, no action is taken.

functions.name: autoSysFields
functions.description: Enables or disables the update to the fields sys_updated_by, sys_updated_on, sys_mod_count, sys_created_by, and sys_created_on. This is often used for manually updating field values on a record while leaving historical information unchanged.

functions.name: canCreate
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit inserting new records in this table.

functions.name: canDelete
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit deletion of records in this table.

functions.name: canRead
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit reading this table.

functions.name: canWrite
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit updates to records in this table.

functions.name: changes
functions.description: Determines whether any of the fields in the record have changed.

functions.name: dateNumericValue
functions.description: Returns the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT for a duration field. Does not require the creation of a GlideDateTime object because the duration field is already a GlideDateTime object.

functions.name: deleteMultiple
functions.description: Deletes multiple records according to the current "where" clause. This method does not delete attachments. Dot-walking is not supported for this method. When using the deleteMultiple() function on referenced tables, all the records in the table are deleted. Also, when using deleteRecord() to cascade delete, prior calls to setWorkflow() on the same GlideRecord object are ignored. Do not use deleteMultiple() on tables with currency fields. Always delete each record individually. Also, do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables.

functions.name: deleteRecord
functions.description: Deletes a single record.

functions.name: find
functions.description: Returns true if any record has a matching value in the specified column. If found, it also moves to the first record that matches, essentially executing next() until the record is returned.

functions.name: get
functions.description: Returns the specified record in an instantiated GlideRecord object. If multiple records are found, use next() to access the additional records.

functions.name: get
functions.description: Returns the specified record in an instantiated GlideRecord object. If multiple records are found, use next() to access the additional records.

functions.name: getAttribute
functions.description: Returns the dictionary attributes on the specified field.

functions.name: getClassDisplayValue
functions.description: Returns the table's label.

functions.name: getDisplayValue
functions.description: Retrieves the display value for the current record.

functions.name: getED
functions.description: Returns the element's descriptor.

functions.name: getElement
functions.description: Retrieves the GlideElement for a specified field.

functions.name: getEncodedQuery
functions.description: Retrieves the encoded query as a string.

functions.name: getEscapedDisplayValue
functions.description: Retrieves the field value for the display field of the current record and adds escape characters for use in Jelly scripts.

functions.name: getFields
functions.description: Retrieves a Java ArrayList of fields in the current record.

functions.name: getLabel
functions.description: Retrieves the field's label.

functions.name: getLink
functions.description: Retrieves the link for the current record.

functions.name: getLocation
functions.description: Retrieves the current row number.

functions.name: getPlural
functions.description: Retrieves the plural label of the GlideRecord table. For example, if the table name is "Change Request," this method returns "Change Requests."

functions.name: getRecordClassName
functions.description: Retrieves the class (table) name for the current record.

functions.name: getRelatedLists
functions.description: Retrieves a list of names and display values of tables that refer to the current record.

functions.name: getRelatedTables
functions.description: Retrieves a list of names and display values of tables that are referred to by the current record.

functions.name: getRowCount
functions.description: Retrieves the number of rows in the GlideRecord object.

functions.name: getRowNumber
functions.description: Retrieves the row number set by saveLocation() or setLocation(). To get the current row number, use getLocation().

functions.name: getTableName
functions.description: Retrieves the table name associated with this GlideRecord.

functions.name: getValue
functions.description: Retrieves the string value of an underlying element in a field.

functions.name: hasAttachments
functions.description: Determines if the current record has any attachments.

functions.name: hasNext
functions.description:
Determines if there are any more records in the GlideRecord.
Consistency across all API ref topics is critical. Follow the template exactly or the importer script will fail.

functions.name: initialize
functions.description: Creates an empty record suitable for population before an insert.

functions.name: insert
functions.description: Inserts a new record using the field values that have been set for the current record.

functions.name: insertWithReferences
functions.description: Inserts a new record and also inserts or updates any related records with the information provided.

functions.name: instanceOf
functions.description: Checks a table for the type\class of table.

functions.name: isNewRecord
functions.description: Determines whether the current record has been inserted into the database. This method returns true only if the newRecord() method has been called. This method is useful for scripted ACL, and in the condition of UI actions, but should not be used in background scripts.

functions.name: isValid
functions.description: Determines if the table exists.

functions.name: isValidField
functions.description: Determines if the specified field is defined in the current table.

functions.name: isValidRecord
functions.description: Determines if the current record is valid.

functions.name: newRecord
functions.description: Creates a GlideRecord, set the default values for the fields and assign a unique id to the record.

functions.name: next
functions.description: Moves to the next record in the GlideRecord. Use this method to iterate through the records returned by a GlideRecord query.

functions.name: operation
functions.description: Retrieves the current operation being performed, such as insert, update, delete, etc.

functions.name: orderBy
functions.description: Specifies a field name to be used to order the query set. This may be called more than once to order by multiple fields.

functions.name: orderByDesc
functions.description: Specifies a field used to order the query set in descending order.

functions.name: query
functions.description: Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(). This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: query
functions.description: Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(). This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: queryNoDomain
functions.description: Used in domain separated instances. Similar to query(), runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(), but ignores domains. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: queryNoDomain
functions.description: Used in domain separated instances. Similar to query(), runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(), but ignores domains. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: restoreLocation
functions.description: Sets the current record to be the record that was saved with saveLocation(). If saveLocation() has not been called, the current record is set to be the first record of the GlideRecord.

functions.name: saveLocation
functions.description: Save the current row number so that we can get back to this location using the restoreLocation() method.

functions.name: setAbortAction
functions.description: Sets a flag to indicate if the next database action (insert, update, delete) is to be aborted. Use in an onBefore business rule to prevent the database action from being done. The business rule continues to run after setAbortAction() is called. Calling setAbortAction() does not stop subsequent business rules from executing. Calling this method only prevents the database action from occurring.

functions.name: setDateNumericValue
functions.description: Sets the duration field to a number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT for a duration field. Does not require the creation of a GlideDateTime object because the duration field is already a GlideDateTime object.

functions.name: setDisplayValue
functions.description: Sets the specified field to the specified display value. For a reference field this is the display value for the table. For a date/time this is the time in the caller's current timezone.

functions.name: setForceUpdate
functions.description: Updates the record even if fields have not changed.

functions.name: setLimit
functions.description: Sets the limit for how many records are in the GlideRecord.

functions.name: setLocation
functions.description: Sets the current row location.

functions.name: setNewGuid
functions.description: Generates a new GUID and sets it as the unique id for the current record. This function applies only to new records. The GUID for an existing record cannot be changed

functions.name: setNewGuidValue
functions.description: Generates a new GUID and sets it as the unique id for the current record, when inserting a new record.

functions.name: setQueryReferences
functions.description: Enables or disables using the reference field's display name when querying a reference field.

functions.name: setUseEngines
functions.description: Disable or enable the running of any engines (approval rules / assignment rules).

functions.name: setValue
functions.description: Sets the specified field to the specified value. Normally a script would do a direct assignment, for example, gr.category = value. However, if in a script the element name is a variable, then gr.setValue(elementName, value) can be used. When setting a value, ensure the data type of the field matches the data type of the value you enter. This method cannot be used on journal fields. If the value parameter is null, the record is not updated, and an error is not thrown.

functions.name: setWorkflow
functions.description: Enables or disables the running of business rules that might normally be triggered by subsequent actions. If the e parameter is set to false, an insert/update will not be audited. Auditing only happens when the parameter is set to true for a GlideRecord operation.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Updates the GlideRecord with any changes that have been made. If the record does not exist, it is inserted.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Updates the GlideRecord with any changes that have been made. If the record does not exist, it is inserted.

functions.name: updateMultiple
functions.description: Updates each GlideRecord in the list with any changes that have been made. When changing field values, use setValue() instead of directly setting the field (field = something). When using updateMultiple(), directly setting the field (gr. state = 4) results in all records in the table being updated instead of just the records returned by the query. Do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables. This method sets new values and does not clear existing values.

functions.name: updateWithReferences
functions.description: Updates a record and also inserts or updates any related records with the information provided.

functions.name: _next
functions.description: Moves to the next record in the GlideRecord. Provides the same functionality as next(), intended to be used in cases where the GlideRecord has a column named next.

functions.name: _query
functions.description: Identical to query(). This method is intended to be used on tables where there is a column named query, which would interfere with using the query() method. Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by the addQuery() and addEncodedQuery() methods. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

This is not a true database join; rather, addJoinQuery adds a subquery. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addNotNullQuery
functions.description: A filter that specifies records where the value of the field passed in the parameter is not null. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. functions.name: addQuery
functions.description: Build a search query and return the rows that match the request. If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the GlideQueryCondition method addOrCondition(). When addQuery() is called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as myObj.addQuery('category','Hardware');, the operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to". Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addQuery
functions.description: Provides the ability to build a request, which when executed, returns the rows from the specified table, that match the request. If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the GlideQueryCondition method addOrCondition(). Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records using an encoded query string. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: setAbortAction
functions.description: Sets a flag to indicate if the next database action (insert, update, delete) is to be aborted. This is often used in business rules. Use in an onBefore business rule to prevent the database action from being done. The business rule continues to run after setAbortAction() is called. Calling setAbortAction() does not stop subsequent business rules from executing. Calling this method only prevents the database action from occurring.

When setting a value, ensure the data type of the field matches the data type of the value you enter.

functions.name: updateMultiple
functions.description: Updates each GlideRecord in the list with any changes that have been made. When changing field values, use setValue() instead of directly setting the field (field = something). When using updateMultiple(), directly setting the field (gr. state = 4) results in all records in the table being updated instead of just the records returned by the query. Do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables. This method sets new values and does not clear existing values.

functions.name: _query

Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by the addQuery() and addEncodedQuery() methods. This method queries the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. Typically this method is called without arguments. If a name/value pair is specified, the "name=value" condition is added to the query.

functions.name: addOrCondition
functions.description:
Appends a two or three parameter OR condition to an existing GlideQueryCondition.
addOrCondition() works in conjunction with any of the addQuery() methods to OR the specified query parameters to the query previously constructed using addQuery().
addOrCondition() is typically called with three parameters; table field, operator, and comparison value. It can be called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as qc.addOrCondition('category', 'software');. The operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to".

functions.name: clearClientData

functions.name: isInteractive
functions.description: Determines if the current session is interactive. An interactive session is one that involves an end-user interacting with a user interface that then retrieves information from a server. An example of this type of session is when a user logs in using the log-in screen or uses a form to query a data store. A non-interactive session is one that only involves programmatic interaction with a server such as a SOAP request to retrieve data.

functions.name: putClientData

functions.name: toggleList
functions.description: Toggles the display of the list and saves the current collapsed/expanded state of the list as a user preference.

functions.name: toggleListNoPref
functions.description: Toggles the display of the list but does not save the current collapsed/expanded state of the list as a user preference.

functions.name: addFilter
functions.description: Adds a single term to the list query filter.

functions.name: get
functions.description: Returns the GlideList object for the specified DOM element.

functions.name: get
functions.description: Returns the GlideList object for specified list.

functions.name: getChecked
functions.description: Returns a comma-separated list of sys_ids for checked items in the list. Does not return items that are not allowed to be executed.

functions.name: getFixedQuery
functions.description: Returns the sysparm_fixed query. The fixed query is the part of the query that cannot be removed from the breadcrumb (i.e., it is fixed for the user). It is specified by including a sysparm_fixed_query parameter for the application module.

functions.name: getFormTarget
functions.description: Returns the form's target attribute.

functions.name: getGroupBy
functions.description: Returns the field or comma-separated list of fields that are used to group the list.

functions.name: getListName
functions.description: Returns the name of the list, which is usually the table name.

functions.name: getOrderBy
functions.description: Returns the first field used to order the list.

functions.name: getParentTable
functions.description: Returns the name of the parent table (the table associated with the form).

functions.name: getQuery
functions.description: Returns the encoded query string for the list.

functions.name: getReferringUrl
functions.description: Returns the referring URL.

functions.name: getRelated
functions.description: Returns the related list field that associates the related list to the parent form.

functions.name: getRelatedListType
functions.description: Returns the related list type.

functions.name: getRelationshipId
functions.description: Returns the relationship record id, if this is type REL related list.

functions.name: getRowCount
functions.description: Returns the number of rows returned by the query.

functions.name: getRowsPerPage
functions.description: Returns the number of rows to be displayed on a page.

functions.name: getTableName
functions.description: Returns the table name of the list.

functions.name: getTitle
functions.description: Returns the list title.

functions.name: getView
functions.description: Returns the view used to display the list.

functions.name: isUserList
functions.description: Returns true if the list has been personalized by the user.

functions.name: refresh
functions.description: Refreshes the list. The orderBy part of the list filter is ignored so that the list's natural ordering is used.

functions.name: refreshWithOrderBy
functions.description: Refreshes the list using the orderBy fields.

functions.name: setFilter
functions.description: Sets the encoded query string for the list ignoring the orderBy and groupBy parts of the query string.

functions.name: setFilterAndRefresh
functions.description: Sets the encoded query string for the list, and then refreshes the list using the new filter. This preserves the groupby and orderby parameters.

functions.name: setFirstRow
functions.description: Sets the first row to be displayed when the list is refreshed.

functions.name: setFormTarget
functions.description: Specifies where to display the response from the form.

functions.name: setGroupBy
functions.description: Sets the groupBy criteria for the list, for a single field or multiple fields. For a single field, use field or groupByField. The groupBy prefix is optional. For multiple fields use field1^field2^field3 or groupByField1^groupByField2^groupByField3.

functions.name: setOrderBy
functions.description: Sets the orderBy criteria for the list. For a single order by field use orderBy field or orderByDescField. For multiple fields, use orderByField1^orderByField2^orderByField3. orderBy specifies ascending order and orderByDesc specifies descending. These prefix strings are optional. If not specified orderBy is assumed.

functions.name: setReferringUrl
functions.description: Sets the parent form referring url.

functions.name: setRowsPerPage
functions.description: Set the number of rows to display on a page.

functions.name: showHideGroups
functions.description: Displays or hides all of the groups within the list and saves the current collapsed/expanded state of the groups as a user preference.

functions.name: showHideList
functions.description: Displays or hides the list and saves the current collapsed/expanded state of the list as a user preference.

functions.name: sort
functions.description: Sort the list in ascending order.

functions.name: sortDescending
functions.description: Sorts the list in descending order.

functions.name: toggleList
functions.description: Toggles the list display between collapsed and expanded, and saves the state as a user preference.

functions.name: toggleListNoPref
functions.description: Toggles the list display between collapsed and expanded, but does not save the state as a user preference.

functions.name: clearImage
functions.description: Clears the image for an item.

functions.name: clearSelected
functions.description: Clears any selection images from items in the menu.

functions.name: getItem
functions.description: Returns a menu item by item ID. It can be necessary to find an item in a menu so that it can be changed before being displayed. Each menu item may be assigned a unique ID when the menu item is created (either from a UI Context Menu entry or from the addAction() method in the Dynamic Script Action).

functions.name: setDisabled
functions.description: Disables a menu item so that it cannot be selected. The disabled menu item is displayed in a lighter color (grayed out) to indicate it is disabled.

functions.name: setEnabled
functions.description: Enables the specified menu item.

functions.name: setHidden
functions.description: Hides the specified menu item. When hiding menu items, the separator bars are not adjusted, so it is possible to end up with the menu showing two separators in a row.

functions.name: setImage
functions.description: Sets an image for an item.

functions.name: setLabel
functions.description: Sets the display label for a menu item. The label may contain HTML.

functions.name: setVisible
functions.description: Displays the specified item.

functions.name: addActiveQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return active records.

functions.name: addDomainQuery
functions.description:
Changes the domain used for the query from the user's domain to the domain of the provided GlideRecord. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.
This function requires the Domain Support - Domain Extensions Installer (com.glide.domain.msp_extensions.installer) plugin.

functions.name: addEncodedQuery
functions.description: Adds an encoded query to other queries that may have been set. Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addFunction
functions.description: Applies a pre-defined GlideDBFunctionBuilder object to a record. Use the GlideDBFunctionBuilder scoped class to define a function. After the function is defined, use the addFunction(Object function) method to apply the function to a record.

functions.name: addInactiveQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return inactive records. Inactive records have the active flag set to false.

functions.name: addJoinQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records based on a relationship in a related table. For example, find all the users that are in the database group (users via sys_user_grmember table). Another example would be find all problems that have an assigned incident (problems via the incident.problem_id relationship). This is not a true database join; rather, addJoinQuery() adds a subquery. So, while the result set is limited based on the join, the only fields that you have access to are those on the base table (those which are in the table with which the GlideRecord was initialized). Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: addNotNullQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records where the specified field is not null.

functions.name: addNullQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return records where the specified field is null.

functions.name: addQuery
functions.description: Provides the ability to build a request, which when executed, returns the rows from the specified table that match the request. If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the class GlideQueryCondition. addQuery() is typically called with three parameters; table field, operator, and comparison value. It can be called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as myObj.addQuery('category','Hardware');. The operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to". Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: applyTemplate
functions.description: Apply a template record (from sys_template) to the current record. If the specified template is not found, no action is taken.

functions.name: autoSysFields
functions.description: Enables or disables the update to the fields sys_updated_by, sys_updated_on, sys_mod_count, sys_created_by, and sys_created_on. This is often used for manually updating field values on a record while leaving historical information unchanged.

functions.name: canCreate
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit inserting new records in this table.

functions.name: canDelete
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit deletion of records in this table.

functions.name: canRead
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit reading this table.

functions.name: canWrite
functions.description: Determines if the access control rules (which includes the user's role) permit updates to records in this table.

functions.name: changes
functions.description: Determines whether any of the fields in the record have changed.

functions.name: dateNumericValue
functions.description: Returns the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT for a duration field. Does not require the creation of a GlideDateTime object because the duration field is already a GlideDateTime object.

functions.name: deleteMultiple
functions.description: Deletes multiple records according to the current "where" clause. This method does not delete attachments. Dot-walking is not supported for this method. When using the deleteMultiple() function on referenced tables, all the records in the table are deleted. Also, when using deleteRecord() to cascade delete, prior calls to setWorkflow() on the same GlideRecord object are ignored. Do not use deleteMultiple() on tables with currency fields. Always delete each record individually. Also, do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables.

functions.name: deleteRecord
functions.description: Deletes a single record.

functions.name: find
functions.description: Returns true if any record has a matching value in the specified column. If found, it also moves to the first record that matches, essentially executing next() until the record is returned.

functions.name: get
functions.description: Returns the specified record in an instantiated GlideRecord object. If multiple records are found, use next() to access the additional records.

functions.name: get
functions.description: Returns the specified record in an instantiated GlideRecord object. If multiple records are found, use next() to access the additional records.

functions.name: getAttribute
functions.description: Returns the dictionary attributes on the specified field.

functions.name: getClassDisplayValue
functions.description: Returns the table's label.

functions.name: getDisplayValue
functions.description: Retrieves the display value for the current record.

functions.name: getED
functions.description: Returns the element's descriptor.

functions.name: getElement
functions.description: Retrieves the GlideElement for a specified field.

functions.name: getEncodedQuery
functions.description: Retrieves the encoded query as a string.

functions.name: getEscapedDisplayValue
functions.description: Retrieves the field value for the display field of the current record and adds escape characters for use in Jelly scripts.

functions.name: getFields
functions.description: Retrieves a Java ArrayList of fields in the current record.

functions.name: getLabel
functions.description: Retrieves the field's label.

functions.name: getLink
functions.description: Retrieves the link for the current record.

functions.name: getLocation
functions.description: Retrieves the current row number.

functions.name: getPlural
functions.description: Retrieves the plural label of the GlideRecord table. For example, if the table name is "Change Request," this method returns "Change Requests."

functions.name: getRecordClassName
functions.description: Retrieves the class (table) name for the current record.

functions.name: getRelatedLists
functions.description: Retrieves a list of names and display values of tables that refer to the current record.

functions.name: getRelatedTables
functions.description: Retrieves a list of names and display values of tables that are referred to by the current record.

functions.name: getRowCount
functions.description: Retrieves the number of rows in the GlideRecord object.

functions.name: getRowNumber
functions.description: Retrieves the row number set by saveLocation() or setLocation(). To get the current row number, use getLocation().

functions.name: getTableName
functions.description: Retrieves the table name associated with this GlideRecord.

functions.name: getValue
functions.description: Retrieves the string value of an underlying element in a field.

functions.name: hasAttachments
functions.description: Determines if the current record has any attachments.

functions.name: hasNext
functions.description: Determines if there are any more records in the GlideRecord.

functions.name: initialize
functions.description: Creates an empty record suitable for population before an insert.

functions.name: insert
functions.description: Inserts a new record using the field values that have been set for the current record.

functions.name: insertWithReferences
functions.description: Inserts a new record and also inserts or updates any related records with the information provided.

functions.name: instanceOf
functions.description: Checks a table for the type\class of table.

functions.name: isNewRecord
functions.description: Determines whether the current record has been inserted into the database. This method returns true only if the newRecord() method has been called. This method is useful for scripted ACL, and in the condition of UI actions, but should not be used in background scripts.

functions.name: isValid
functions.description: Determines if the table exists.

functions.name: isValidField
functions.description: Determines if the specified field is defined in the current table.

functions.name: isValidRecord
functions.description: Determines if the current record is valid.

functions.name: newRecord
functions.description: Creates a GlideRecord, set the default values for the fields and assign a unique id to the record.

functions.name: next
functions.description: Moves to the next record in the GlideRecord. Use this method to iterate through the records returned by a GlideRecord query.

functions.name: operation
functions.description: Retrieves the current operation being performed, such as insert, update, delete, etc.

functions.name: orderBy
functions.description: Specifies a field name to be used to order the query set. This may be called more than once to order by multiple fields.

functions.name: orderByDesc
functions.description: Specifies a field used to order the query set in descending order.

functions.name: query
functions.description: Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(). This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: query
functions.description: Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(). This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: queryNoDomain
functions.description: Used in domain separated instances. Similar to query(), runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(), but ignores domains. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: queryNoDomain
functions.description: Used in domain separated instances. Similar to query(), runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(), but ignores domains. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: restoreLocation
functions.description: Sets the current record to be the record that was saved with saveLocation(). If saveLocation() has not been called, the current record is set to be the first record of the GlideRecord.

functions.name: saveLocation
functions.description: Save the current row number so that we can get back to this location using the restoreLocation() method.

functions.name: setAbortAction
functions.description: Sets a flag to indicate if the next database action (insert, update, delete) is to be aborted. Use in an onBefore business rule to prevent the database action from being done. The business rule continues to run after setAbortAction() is called. Calling setAbortAction() does not stop subsequent business rules from executing. Calling this method only prevents the database action from occurring.

functions.name: setDateNumericValue
functions.description: Sets the duration field to a number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT for a duration field. Does not require the creation of a GlideDateTime object because the duration field is already a GlideDateTime object.

functions.name: setDisplayValue
functions.description: Sets the specified field to the specified display value. For a reference field this is the display value for the table. For a date/time this is the time in the caller's current timezone.

functions.name: setForceUpdate
functions.description: Updates the record even if fields have not changed.

functions.name: setLimit
functions.description: Sets the limit for how many records are in the GlideRecord.

functions.name: setLocation
functions.description: Sets the current row location.

functions.name: setNewGuid
functions.description: Generates a new GUID and sets it as the unique id for the current record. This function applies only to new records. The GUID for an existing record cannot be changed

functions.name: setNewGuidValue
functions.description: Generates a new GUID and sets it as the unique id for the current record, when inserting a new record.

functions.name: setQueryReferences
functions.description: Enables or disables using the reference field's display name when querying a reference field.

functions.name: setUseEngines
functions.description: Disable or enable the running of any engines (approval rules / assignment rules).

functions.name: setValue
functions.description: Sets the specified field to the specified value. Normally a script would do a direct assignment, for example, gr.category = value. However, if in a script the element name is a variable, then gr.setValue(elementName, value) can be used. When setting a value, ensure the data type of the field matches the data type of the value you enter. This method cannot be used on journal fields. If the value parameter is null, the record is not updated, and an error is not thrown.

functions.name: setWorkflow
functions.description: Enables or disables the running of business rules that might normally be triggered by subsequent actions. If the e parameter is set to false, an insert/update will not be audited. Auditing only happens when the parameter is set to true for a GlideRecord operation.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Updates the GlideRecord with any changes that have been made. If the record does not exist, it is inserted.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Updates the GlideRecord with any changes that have been made. If the record does not exist, it is inserted.

functions.name: updateMultiple
functions.description: Updates each GlideRecord in the list with any changes that have been made. When changing field values, use setValue() instead of directly setting the field (field = something). When using updateMultiple(), directly setting the field (gr. state = 4) results in all records in the table being updated instead of just the records returned by the query. Do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables. This method sets new values and does not clear existing values.

functions.name: updateWithReferences
functions.description: Updates a record and also inserts or updates any related records with the information provided.

functions.name: _next
functions.description: Moves to the next record in the GlideRecord. Provides the same functionality as next(), intended to be used in cases where the GlideRecord has a column named next.

functions.name: _query
functions.description: Identical to query(). This method is intended to be used on tables where there is a column named query, which would interfere with using the query() method. Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by the addQuery() and addEncodedQuery() methods. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: _query
functions.description: Identical to query(). This method is intended to be used on tables where there is a column named query, which would interfere with using the query() method. Runs the query against the table based on the filters specified by the addQuery() and addEncodedQuery() methods. This will query the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. One argument adds a query string. Usually this is performed without arguments, but a name/value pair can be specified.

functions.name: addActiveQuery
functions.description: Adds a filter to return active records.

functions.name: addFunction
functions.description: Applies a pre-defined GlideDBFunctionBuilder object to a record. Use the GlideDBFunctionBuilder scoped class to define a function. After the function is defined, use the addFunction(Object function) method to apply the function to a record.

An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. functions.name: addQuery
functions.description: Provides the ability to build a request, which when executed, returns the rows from the specified table, that match the request. If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the GlideQueryCondition method addOrCondition(). When addQuery() is called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as myObj.addQuery('category','Hardware');, the operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to". Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss. You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

functions.name: setAbortAction
functions.description: Sets a flag to indicate if the next database action (insert, update, delete) is to be aborted. This is often used in business rules. Use in an onBefore business rule to prevent the database action from being done. The business rule continues to run after setAbortAction() is called. Calling setAbortAction() does not stop subsequent business rules from executing. Calling this method only prevents the database action from occurring.

When setting a value, ensure the data type of the field matches the data type of the value you enter.

functions.name: updateMultiple
functions.description: Updates each GlideRecord in the list with any changes that have been made. When changing field values, use setValue() instead of directly setting the field (field = something). When using updateMultiple(), directly setting the field (gr. state = 4) results in all records in the table being updated instead of just the records returned by the query. Do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables. This method sets new values and does not clear existing values.

functions.name: _query

Typically this method is called without arguments. If a name/value pair is specified, the "name=value" condition is added to the query.

functions.name: addOrCondition
functions.description:
Appends a two or three parameter OR condition to an existing GlideQueryCondition.
addOrCondition() works in conjunction with any of the addQuery() methods to OR the specified query parameters to the query previously constructed using addQuery().
addOrCondition() is typically called with three parameters; table field, operator, and comparison value. It can be called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as qc.addOrCondition('category', 'software');. The operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to".

functions.name: isInteractive
functions.description: Determines if the current session is interactive. An interactive session is one that involves an end-user interacting with a user interface that then retrieves information from a server. An example of this type of session is when a user logs in using the log-in screen or uses a form to query a data store. A non-interactive session is one that only involves programmatic interaction with a server such as a SOAP request to retrieve data.

functions.description: Returns the sysparm_fixed query. The fixed query is the part of the query that cannot be removed from the breadcrumb (i.e., it is fixed for the user). It is specified by including a sysparm_fixed_query parameter for the application module.

functions.name: getFormTarget
functions.description: Returns the form's target attribute.

functions.name: getGroupBy
functions.description: Returns the field or comma-separated list of fields that are used to group the list.

functions.name: getListName
functions.description: Returns the name of the list, which is usually the table name.

functions.name: getOrderBy
functions.description: Returns the first field used to order the list.

functions.name: getParentTable
functions.description: Returns the name of the parent table (the table associated with the form).

functions.name: getQuery
functions.description: Returns the encoded query string for the list.

functions.name: getReferringUrl
functions.description: Returns the referring URL.

functions.name: getRelated
functions.description: Returns the related list field that associates the related list to the parent form.

functions.name: getRelatedListType
functions.description: Returns the related list type.

functions.name: getRelationshipId
functions.description: Returns the relationship record id, if this is type REL related list.

functions.name: getRowCount
functions.description: Returns the number of rows returned by the query.

functions.name: getRowsPerPage
functions.description: Returns the number of rows to be displayed on a page.

functions.name: getTableName
functions.description: Returns the table name of the list.

functions.name: getTitle
functions.description: Returns the list title.

functions.name: getView
functions.description: Returns the view used to display the list.

functions.name: isUserList
functions.description: Returns true if the list has been personalized by the user.

functions.name: refresh
functions.description: Refreshes the list. The orderBy part of the list filter is ignored so that the list's natural ordering is used.

functions.name: refreshWithOrderBy
functions.description: Refreshes the list using the orderBy fields.

functions.name: setFilter
functions.description: Sets the encoded query string for the list ignoring the orderBy and groupBy parts of the query string.

functions.name: setFilterAndRefresh
functions.description: Sets the encoded query string for the list, and then refreshes the list using the new filter. This preserves the groupby and orderby parameters.

functions.name: setFirstRow
functions.description: Sets the first row to be displayed when the list is refreshed.

functions.name: setFormTarget
functions.description: Specifies where to display the response from the form.

functions.name: setGroupBy
functions.description: Sets the groupBy criteria for the list, for a single field or multiple fields. For a single field, use field or groupByField. The groupBy prefix is optional. For multiple fields use field1^field2^field3 or groupByField1^groupByField2^groupByField3.

functions.name: setOrderBy
functions.description: Sets the orderBy criteria for the list. For a single order by field use orderBy field or orderByDescField. For multiple fields, use orderByField1^orderByField2^orderByField3. orderBy specifies ascending order and orderByDesc specifies descending. These prefix strings are optional. If not specified orderBy is assumed.

functions.name: setReferringUrl
functions.description: Sets the parent form referring url.

functions.name: setRowsPerPage
functions.description: Set the number of rows to display on a page.

functions.name: showHideGroups
functions.description: Displays or hides all of the groups within the list and saves the current collapsed/expanded state of the groups as a user preference.

functions.name: showHideList
functions.description: Displays or hides the list and saves the current collapsed/expanded state of the list as a user preference.

functions.name: sort
functions.description: Sort the list in ascending order.

functions.name: sortDescending
functions.description: Sorts the list in descending order.

functions.name: toggleList
functions.description: Toggles the list display between collapsed and expanded, and saves the state as a user preference.

functions.name: toggleListNoPref
functions.description: Toggles the list display between collapsed and expanded, but does not save the state as a user preference.

functions.name: clearImage
functions.description: Clears the image for an item.

functions.name: clearSelected
functions.description: Clears any selection images from items in the menu.

functions.name: getItem
functions.description: Returns a menu item by item ID. It can be necessary to find an item in a menu so that it can be changed before being displayed. Each menu item may be assigned a unique ID when the menu item is created (either from a UI Context Menu entry or from the addAction() method in the Dynamic Script Action).

functions.name: setDisabled
functions.description: Disables a menu item so that it cannot be selected. The disabled menu item is displayed in a lighter color (grayed out) to indicate it is disabled.

functions.name: setEnabled
functions.description: Enables the specified menu item.

functions.name: setHidden
functions.description: Hides the specified menu item. When hiding menu items, the separator bars are not adjusted, so it is possible to end up with the menu showing two separators in a row.

functions.name: setImage
functions.description: Sets an image for an item.

functions.name: setLabel
functions.description: Sets the display label for a menu item. The label may contain HTML.

functions.name: setVisible
functions.description: Displays the specified item.
